paper_metadata.title: Evaluating anti-poverty programs using satellite imagery and deep learning

component_a_cash_support.cash_evidence_citation: GiveDirectly, a US charity, implemented a randomized controlled trial of unconditional cash transfers to rural households via mobile money, using as sole eligibility criterion whether the household lived under a thatched roof... Each treatment household received $1,000-equivalent to about 75% of annual household expenditures-in lump sum, and could spend it however it wished.

study_characteristics.outcomes_evidence_citation: We then map housing quality to household wealth for these households by inverting an 'Engel curve,'... to measure program impacts as is the current practice in the evaluation literature.
study_characteristics.design_evidence_citation: GiveDirectly randomly selected 328 villages as the treatment group, where eligible households (about 1/3 of the population) received transfers, and used the remaining 325 villages as the control group.

bonus_information.cost_mentions: Cost of $0.006 per household for satellite approach vs $18-300 per household for surveys
bonus_information.cost_evidence_citation: Using this approach, we accurately recover the program effects on household wealth for a fraction of the cost ($0.006 per household, see Supplementary Text A) that would typically be spent on household surveys ($18-300 per household)

evidence_citations.program_name_citation: GiveDirectly, a US charity, implemented a randomized controlled trial of unconditional cash transfers to rural households via mobile money
evidence_citations.country_citation: We evaluate a development intervention that was conducted in 2014-2017 in 653 villages in rural Kenya
evidence_citations.target_population_citation: using as sole eligibility criterion whether the household lived under a thatched roof (a low quality roof material that served as a simple means test)
